title: Alabama Governor Is Latest GOP Official to Urge Vaccinations
summary: Delta variant surges amid lower rates of vaccinations among Republicans, fueling charges from Democrats that the GOP hasn't sufficiently countered vaccine skepticism. Alabama's Republican governor made an urgent plea for residents to get vaccinated to slow a surge in Covid-19 cases, becoming the latest top GOP official to step up calls for inoculations in the face of vaccine hesitancy among conservative voters.

title: John Legend and Chrissy Teigen's Swanky Home in Beverly Hills
summary: The home is full of luxurious details and has its own 'glam room.'. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: John Legend and Chrissy Teigen Sell Beverly Hills Home for $16.8 Million
summary: The celebrity pair first listed the 8,500-square-foot property for $23.95 million last year, but recently cut the price to $17.7 million. Musician John Legend and his wife, model and social-media celebrity Chrissy Teigen, have sold their Beverly Hills home for about $16.8 million, according to their listing agent Marshall Peck of Douglas Elliman.

title: Progressive Gun-Control Crackup
summary: Defense lawyers ask the Supreme Court to affirm gun rights.. For the elite left, opposition to gun rights is in part a cultural statement of antipathy to red-state values. Yet a small but important part of the progressive coalition-criminal-defense lawyers-can't afford to treat gun laws as one more culture-war bludgeon. Hence a remarkable amicus brief by a coalition of defense lawyers for the indigent, led by the Black Attorneys of Legal Aid, asking the Supreme Court to expand gun rights in the Second Amendment case it will decide next term.

title: Taking the 'Bi' Out of Bipartisan
summary: Are Republicans getting any policy victories from the infrastructure deal?. Senate negotiators still haven't released the details of their bipartisan infrastructure deal, though it could come to a vote on the floor as early as next week. What's striking about the deal so far, however, is that by all appearances this will be the most one-sided bipartisan deal in decades.

title: Deb Haaland's Oil and Gas Stall
summary: The Interior Secretary ignores a federal judge on drilling leases.. A federal judge in Louisiana last month blocked President Biden's suspension of new oil and gas leasing on federal land and ordered the Administration to resume auctions. Interior Secretary Deb Haaland on Thursday gave the judge the back of her hand.

title: Congress Beats Up Charter Schools
summary: A House spending bill cuts funding and adds new political strings.. Democrats in Washington say they want to reduce inequality. So why are they running a guerrilla campaign against charter schools that help so many children escape educational inequality?

title: U.S. Buys 200 Million Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccines at Higher Price
summary: The price is higher than the $19.50 in previous deals, which Pfizer says reflects additional packaging and formulations. The U.S. has purchased 200 million additional Covid-19 vaccine doses from Pfizer Inc. and partner BioNTech SE , at a higher price than previous deals.

title: Al Lord Profited When Tuition Rose. He Is Paying For It.
summary: As chief executive of student-lending giant Sallie Mae, Al Lord helped drive up the costs of college. Now that he is footing tuition checks for his grandchildren, he said he has new sympathy for ordinary families.. Al Lord, the former chief executive of student-loan giant Sallie Mae , has a complaint about higher education: The price of college is too damn high.

title: 2022 EQS 580 4Matic: Mercedes's Answer to the Tesla Model S
summary: With the EQS, Daimler introduces the first of four Mercedes-EQ models that will share an all-new electric architecture. Should Elon Musk be worried? Dan Neil doesn't think so.. the Oberalpstrasse is a two-lane road winding over and sometimes through the Swiss Alps, by way of thrilling, kilometers-long tunnels. It's famous as one of the great driving roads in Europe, and on any sunny summer day it can turn into a conga line of rented Harleys and caravans. But on this occasion-a cool, wet Thursday morning, July 15-I had the Alps almost to myself. Just me and the mighty 2022 EQS 580 4Matic Sedan, an all-electric S-Class from Daimler's Mercedes-EQ sub-brand. In the EQS you never ride alone.

title: Texas Provides a Model for Conservative Healthcare Reform
summary: Republicans passed a package of market-friendly laws to expand access and increase competition.. The Supreme Court ruled in 2012 that the federal government couldn't force states to expand Medicaid as part of the Affordable Care Act. Ever since, Democrats and hospital lobbyists have looked for ways to push state legislators to let able-bodied adults earning up to 138% of the federal poverty level into Medicaid. In the last Covid relief bill, Democrats tried to give states more temporary money to expand Medicaid. Now they are considering legislation to allow Democratic cities in Republican states to expand Medicaid on their own. But Texas Republicans have modeled a better way to get Americans affordable healthcare.

title: My Old Truck Spoke Louder Than Words
summary: Keith Whitley was correct about the power of nonverbal communication.. My wife, Devin, and I chose as our wedding song "When You Say Nothing at All," the country paean to nonverbal communication popularized by Keith Whitley in 1988. Only later did I appreciate how this song spoke to more than affairs of the heart.

title: The Tokyo Olympics' Staggering Price Tag and Where It Stands in History
summary: Mounting pandemic challenges pushed the cost of the Summer Games to an unprecedented high. The Tokyo Olympics are set to be the most expensive Olympics on record. According to officials, the budget is $15.4 billion, but Japanese government auditors have said total spending tops $20 billion, almost three times the original forecast of around $7.4 billion when Tokyo put together its bid for the Olympics. That puts the Games $11.04 billion over the total cost of London's Olympics, the next most expensive ever.

title: Why Space Tourism? Because It Operates Outside of NASA
summary: But fans of space exploration know big government will likely always take the lead.. These have been heady days for would-be space tourists, a self-funding cargo that spacecraft designer Burt Rutan once joked can be reproduced with unskilled labor around the house.

title: Bezos, Branson and the Vikings
summary: They risk their lives to venture into uncharted territory in search of opportunity for the world.. Richard Branson's and Jeff Bezos' ventures into space tapped into a perennial fascination with manned space travel that dates back to the Apollo moon program in the 1960s and '70s and even to the 19th-century novels of Jules Verne. But as a historian of globalization and technology, I think in centuries. I see strong parallels between today's billionaire space race and the Viking raiders and explorers of the Middle Ages.

title: Rage and Protests Mark Funeral of Haiti's Slain President
summary: Resume Subscription. PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti-In front of a mourning family and foreign dignitaries, President Jovenel Moïse was laid to rest Friday in a country riven by deepening strife two weeks after his assassination.

title: Haiti President Assassinated: What We Know About Jovenel Moïse's Killing
summary: Police say more than 30 people in Haiti, the U.S. and Colombia are implicated in the conspiracy. Gunmen assassinated Haitian President Jovenel Moïse on July 7, storming his house in the capital in an attack in which first lady Martine Moïse was wounded. Haitian police say more than 30 people are implicated in the plot, including businessmen, former officials, former Colombian soldiers and a Haitian pastor and self-described doctor who they accuse of seeking to become president.

title: 'Maya Beiser x Philip Glass' Review: Reforging Minimalism
summary: A cellist's rendition of eight works by the influential avant-garde composer is enhanced by her use of multitracking and dimensional tone..

title: Dow Tops 35000 as Stocks Rise to Records
summary: The three major U.S. stock indexes seal all-time highs after reversing Monday's selloff. U.S. stocks rallied Friday, pushing the Dow Jones Industrial Average across the 35000 closing milestone for the first time, in a striking rebound from major indexes' pullback earlier this week.

title: Shares of Chinese Tutoring Companies Plummet on Crackdown Fears
summary: China has said it wants to reduce the financial burdens of parenthood, including education. Concerns about a Chinese government crackdown on after-school tutoring hammered shares in Chinese education stocks.

title: The Murder Spike of 2020: When Police Pull Back
summary: A criminologist argues that last year's unprecedented rise in killings was the result of treating policing as a problem to be solved, rather than an essential part of public order. The rise in murders in the U.S. in 2020 was unprecedented. Complete nationwide data for the year won't be available until September, but we already know that in 70 cities and counties that account for a fifth of the U.S. population, the murder rate rose by 35%. The largest previous increase on record was 13% in 1968-a year that, like 2020, was marked by civil unrest, often triggered by police misconduct, leading to demands for police reform.

title: 'Deepfake': A Piece of Thieves' Slang Gets a Digital Twist
summary: A 21st-century term for manipulated audio or video updates a word used by 19th-century Australian convicts. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: Tamarack and Bootleg Fires in the West Grow Amid Difficult Conditions
summary: Wildfires are burning across more than 1.3 million acres in the U.S. as dry conditions in the West fuel their growth. The Tamarack Fire, which has been burning for two weeks south of Lake Tahoe in California, grew more than 2,500 acres Thursday and has jumped into Nevada, prompting new evacuations and power outages.

title: Chipotle, Apple, Zoom, Intel: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news.

title: Huawei Hires Democratic Lobbyist Tony Podesta
summary: Hiring comes amid renewed D.C. lobbying push by company that was target of Trump administration. Huawei Technologies Co. has hired veteran Democratic lobbyist Tony Podesta-whose firm imploded in 2017 amid financial and legal troubles-as part of the Chinese company's expanded U.S. influence operation, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: The Summer Fauxlympics (Saturday Crossword, July 24)

What to Read This Week
summary: Love and death in a utopian community, the remorseless business of slavery, a passion for peacocks, updating Sir Gawain and more..

title: Politics: The Minders and Mandarins of Capitalism
summary: Exploring fallacies about economics-and the problem of putting faith in experts.. James R. Otteson's "Seven Deadly Economic Sins" (Cambridge, 305 pages, $27.95) is a fine effort to introduce readers to the basic principles of market economics. The hamartiological framing-the "sins" are bad assumptions about how markets work-is part of the author's effort to make the subject more engaging than a typical treatise on economics. It works. Mr. Otteson, a professor of business ethics at Notre Dame, writes with an apt combination of casual wit and rigorous logic.

title: Kimberly-Clark Plans Higher Prices Through Next Year
summary: Company's results fall short of expectations due to higher costs and shrinking demand for toilet paper, other pandemic staples. The maker of Huggies diapers and Cottonelle toilet paper said it expects to charge higher prices through 2022 in an effort to offset rising costs.

title: Trump Ally Tom Barrack Freed on $250 Million Bond
summary: The real-estate investor and former Trump adviser will appear in federal court Monday on charges that he acted as a U.A.E. foreign agent and lied to federal investigators. Tom Barrack, the real-estate investor and longtime ally of former President Donald Trump, was freed from detention Friday on $250 million bond after striking a deal with federal prosecutors for his release before trial on charges that he worked as a foreign agent of the United Arab Emirates.

title: Why Everyone from Olivia Rodrigo to Multitasking Moms Is Wearing a Mini Bag
summary: Post-lockdown, women are swapping cumbersome work totes for comically small tiny bags. Some insist they're liberating. Others, like rapper Lizzo, have found they're dynamite Instagram fodder.. WHEN PROTON-SIZE purses went viral in 2019, sensible sorts dismissed the trend as a mildly amusing Instagram joke. "Come on, what can you really carry in that?" Michele Vidal, 36, thought to herself each time she saw an itsy-bitsy Jacquemus Le Chiquito bag, the Petit version of which is just 2 inches long, on her social media feed. Such minuscule designs seemed better suited for her 8-year-old daughter's doll than a full-grown woman. Recently, however, the Easton, Penn.-based lifestyle influencer has revised her position. "They're totally functional," said Ms. Vidal, who now owns three micro bags, including a gilded Chanel number she had a personal shopper track down in Hong Kong. "I'm always shopping for them. It's kind of an obsession."

title: France Passes New Bill to Tighten Control of Mosques
summary: Move has been framed as a response to the spread of Islamist separatism in the country. PARIS-The French Parliament passed a bill on Friday that aims to strengthen government oversight of mosques and other religious organizations and counter the influence of Islamist movements that French President Emmanuel Macron says are undermining the country's secular values.

title: The Maker of Long-Lasting Lipstick Is Kissing Her Orange County Home Goodbye
summary: Joni Rogers-Kante, who developed LipSense in the 1990s, is listing the Irvine, Calif., property she bought with her husband for $49.95 million. An elaborate Orange County estate whose owner made a fortune selling long-lasting lipstick is coming to the market for $49.95 million.

summary: This lavish, 13,000-square-foot home is fully customized with ornate millwork and upholstered walls. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Supply-Chain Backlogs Turn Chicago Into New Chokepoint
summary: Some railroads have restricted container shipments into the key Midwestern freight hub as bottlenecks from a flood of container imports stretch inland from the West Coast. Chicago is emerging as a new bottleneck in the global supply chain as rail, trucking and logistics operators struggle with a glut of imports from Asia reaching the Midwestern freight hub.

title: New Aid Coming for Mortgage Borrowers at Foreclosure Risk
summary: Biden administration aims to reduce monthly payments by up to 25% for those with federally backed mortgages who are at the end of forbearance. Borrowers who fell behind on their mortgages during the Covid-19 pandemic and continue to face economic hardship will get help from a Biden administration program announced on Friday, a bid to prevent a sharp rise in foreclosures over the coming months.

title: Artists Explore New Ways of Sculpting the Land
summary: New exhibitions at the Nevada Museum of Art spotlight the state's central role in the evolving land art movement. In 1969, a young artist named Michael Heizer headed into the Nevada desert 80 miles northeast of Las Vegas and cut a pair of trenches into a mesa, running 50 feet deep, 30 feet wide and a combined 1,500 feet long. Monumental enough to be seen in satellite photographs, "Double Negative" quickly became an icon in the emerging field of land art-art that uses land itself as its material, by marking, sculpting or otherwise intervening in the landscape.

title: How Science Lost the Public's Trust
summary: From climate to Covid, politics and hubris have disconnected scientific institutions from the philosophy and method that ought to guide them.. 'Science" has become a political catchword. "I believe in science," Joe Bidentweeted six days before he was elected president. "Donald Trump doesn't. It's that simple, folks."

title: The Temptation of Judging for the 'Common Good'
summary: Conservatives finally have a Supreme Court majority. Some on the right want judicial activism too.. As liberals lick their wounds from the recent Supreme Court term, a small but noisy band on the right has launched a dissent against the conservative legal movement that produced the court's majority. They want a new jurisprudence of "moral substance" that elevates conservative results over legalistic or procedural questions such as individual rights, limited government and separation of powers. Some advocates call this idea "common good originalism," but it isn't originalism. It's no different from the raw-power judicial activism conservatives have railed against for decades as unaccountable, unwise and dangerous.

title: Boston Beer Shares Fall After Hard-Seltzer Demand Sputters
summary: Company missed Wall Street projections for earnings and sales for the fiscal second quarter. Boston Beer Co. Inc. lost about a quarter of its value after it said demand for Truly hard seltzers was lower than anticipated.

title: Oil Servicers Climb Out of a Hole
summary: Oil-field services companies, which started tightening their belts in 2019, say the worst is now behind them. Oil-field services companies have been in bunker mode for a while. They are finally starting to see some daylight.

title: West Virginia Governor's Companies Look to Pay Off Greensill Debts
summary: Representatives of Credit Suisse and Mr. Justice's companies met to sort out nearly $850 million in loans tied to Greensill. West Virginia Gov. Jim Justice and Credit Suisse Group AG are looking to take advantage of surging coal prices to help him pay off nearly $850 million in loans his companies borrowed from now-collapsed Greensill Capital.

title: Pfizer Vaccine Found Less Effective Against Delta Infections but Still Prevents Serious Illness
summary: Vaccine was 39% effective at reducing infection risk and 91% effective at preventing severe illness, Health Ministry says. TEL AVIV-Data from Israel suggests Pfizer Inc.'s vaccine has become less effective in preventing infection of Covid-19 in recent weeks, although it remains a robust bulwark against serious illness as governments around the world scramble to respond to the rampant spread of a new Delta variant of the coronavirus

title: Honest Californian Takes On Tax Issue
summary: Football star D.J. Uiagalelei is not the first Golden Stater to consider a future in Nevada.. News consumers have lately been amused by creative efforts to avoid explaining why people are fleeing California. But there is at least one forthright Californian willing to explain why he's considering a future outside the Golden State.

title: How Bezos' Space Watch Became a Marketing Win for Omega
summary: The Blue Origin and Amazon founder's conspicuous wristwatch led to a surge of interest in the Swiss watchmaker. JEFF BEZOS' Blue Origin mission on Tuesday wasn't just a landmark event in private space travel. It was also a shrewd marketing opportunity for one of the world's top high-end watch makers. As Mr. Bezos posed for pictures and chatted with CNN reporters following the launch, he had a shimmering Omega wristwatch strapped conspicuously on the exterior of his jumpsuit.

title: Yaki Onigiri with Soy and Miso Glazes

title: Physician Leana Wen Is a Public-Health Pragmatist
summary: A Rhodes scholar and ER veteran works to address the root causes of medical problems before they become emergencies. Leana Wen was a medical student when she first saw "the limitations of our healthcare system," she says. She remembers vividly an 8-year-old boy with severe asthma who would come to the emergency room wheezing and coughing. After hours of treatments he was usually well enough to leave, but he was often back a few days later, frightened and gasping for breath.

summary: Each bite of this deconstructed salad includes a salty pop from the roe, cool smoke from the cucumbers, and a hint of sweetness and bitterness from the radicchio, rounded out by a lively citrus punch and herbal finish. title: The Problem With Employer Health Insurance
summary: It covers those healthy enough to work, and gives them little reason to economize.. While I agree with Casey Mulligan that employer health insurance is much better than the government alternative ("Three Cheers for Employer Health Insurance," op-ed, July 17), it is far from a panacea. Having dealt with it as a physician, patient and employer, our current system leaves much to be desired.

title: Grilled Watermelon Ginger Popsicles
summary: This recipe brilliantly combines the smoke of outdoor grilling with summer's favorite sweet, icy refreshment on a stick. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Global Recovery Accelerates, but Delta Clouds Outlook
summary: Parts of the world are expected to surge in coming months as red-hot U.S. growth begins to ease. Parts of the global economy are expected to surge over the coming months and start to catch up with the U.S. and China, though the Delta variant of Covid-19 looms as a potential headwind, according to surveys of purchasing managers.

title: Contest Crosswords 101
Get More From Your Grill: Recipes for Busting a Barbecue Rut
summary: This summer, chefs are grilling audaciously, putting a delicious char on avocados, romaine, gnudi, even ice cream. Take their hot tips and get adventurous with what you toss on the grate, with recipes to please vegans and omnivores alike.. I HATE GOING to barbecues," a vegetarian friend once confided as she poked at flavorless charred zucchini and bell peppers, an obvious afterthought by our host that evening. That's why the grilled avocado made such an impression on me during a recent meal at Daniel Boulud's Le Pavillon, recently opened in New York City. The soft green fruit possessed a perfect crisscross of brown grill marks. Adorned with einkorn and tart goji berries, the dish got a touch of spice from harissa and an additional hit of smoky flavor from charred kale. This clever combination would make a satisfying dish for most any diner, regardless of dietary habits.

title: GM Recalls Chevy Bolts for Second Time Due to Fire Risk
summary: The company is advising owners of 2017-19 model year vehicles to keep their charges at a certain level and to park them outside after charging. General Motors Co. is recalling its all-electric Chevrolet Bolt for a second time because of a potential battery defect that can cause a fire, underscoring the technical challenges car companies face as they race to develop more plug-in vehicles.

title: Contest Crosswords 101 Part 1: Poetic Justice
Warren Targets Sacklers' Legal Protection in Purdue Bankruptcy
summary: 'If the Sacklers want to stop those lawsuits, they can file for bankruptcy just like normal people do,' the Massachusetts senator says. Sen. Elizabeth Warren is bolstering efforts by Democratic lawmakers to stop the owners of OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP from using the company's bankruptcy to shield themselves from lawsuits blaming them for the opioid crisis.

title: Biden Says 'America Is Back,' but Why Is It Closed?
summary: There is no reason the U.S. cannot reciprocate and open to fully vaccinated Europeans.. The Biden administration's aim to restore American global leadership is being undermined by its continuing entry ban for non-American travelers from Europe, a complaint raised by German Chancellor Angela Merkel during her recent visit to the White House. ("Biden Welcomes Merkel for Her Final Visit as Germany's Chancellor," World News, July 16.)

title: Contest Crosswords 101 Part 2: Chemical Change
A Stadium-Sized Listening Party in Atlanta for Kanye West's 'Donda'
summary: The rapper-provocateur previewed more than a dozen tracks about family, loss and religion at the stadium-sized listening party. ATLANTA-Kanye West is known for rising to the occasion when the chips are down. The rapper cut a solitary figure-standing alone in a cavernous stadium without uttering a word-during a listening party on Thursday night in Atlanta for his new album "Donda."

title: Summer Games Opening Ceremony Skips Usual Razzle-Dazzle
summary: Resume Subscription. The Olympics opened with dance performances highlighting the struggle to overcome the pandemic and tennis star Naomi Osaka lighting a cauldron with the symbolic flame of the Games.

title: Contest Crosswords 101 Part 3: In Character
Contest Crosswords 101 Part 4: Looking for That Spark
Randi Weingarten Dodges On Critical Race Theory
summary: The teachers union president deflects focus from its true tenets.. In "Teachers Union Responds on Woke Education" (Letters, July 16), American Federation of Teachers President Randi Weingarten justifies teaching critical race theory in our schools by citing examples of historical racism allegedly being glossed over or omitted. But most Americans support teaching students about slavery, racism and their devastating effects.

title: How to Watch the Tokyo Olympics Opening Ceremony and Key Times
summary: NBC is televising the opening ceremony live, with a re-broadcast beginning at 7:30 p.m. Eastern time. After a year's delay, the opening ceremony of the Tokyo Summer Olympics is finally happening. Here's a guide:

title: Psiphon's Anti-Censorship Network Works for Cubans
summary: The CEO writes that his company has provided access to 2.8 million in Cuba in the past week.. Regarding "Tearing Down Cuba's Cyberwall" (Review & Outlook, July 19): During the past week Psiphon has provided access to more than 2.8 million Cubans and 1,100,000 gigabytes of data on the Psiphon anti-censorship network (an average of 380 megabytes of data per person) free of charge and without speed limitation. Contrary to the article, that is certainly not slow.

title: How Corporate America Became a Political Orphan
summary: With populism on the rise in the GOP and the Democrats moving left, the business community is struggling to find allies in a polarized era. American business leaders increasingly have been pulled into-or in some cases have dived willingly into-the hot cauldron of today's political system. How's that going? Consider events that unfolded within a matter of days recently.

title: Cleveland Indians to Change Name to Guardians
summary: The MLB team announced its intent to change the name late last year. Cleveland's Major League Baseball team will change its name to the Guardians starting at the end of the 2021 season, the franchise announced on Friday, dropping the name "Indians," which had been criticized as racist.

title: Why Investors Can't Kick the 'Past Performance' Habit
summary: Market history never repeats itself exactly. Trying to convince people otherwise can backfire.. On Monday, July 19, financial markets hit instant replay.

title: 'The Gun, the Ship, and the Pen' Review: Noble Aspirations, Hard Realities
summary: Constitutions throughout the world give form to high-minded principle, but rivalry and war brought them into existence.. 'War made the state," the sociologist Charles Tilly famously wrote, "and the state made war." In "The Gun, the Ship, and the Pen" (Liveright, 502 pages, $35), the distinguished historian Linda Colley implicitly refashions Tilly's maxim, arguing that war made constitutions and that constitutions made war.

title: 'Better to Have Gone' Review: Dawn of a New Humanity
summary: Seekers from around the world flocked to an Indian community under the guidance of the woman they called 'The Mother.'. Utopias are not, by definition, found on this side of paradise. Yet that truth hasn't stopped visionaries and seekers-not to mention knaves and fools-from trying to build communities on lofty principles and quixotic aspirations. One such wonderland is Auroville, a commune in India's Tamil south whose heady origins can be traced to the incense-and-raga days of the 1960s. Akash Kapur's "Better to Have Gone" (Scribner, 344 pages, $27) is a haunting and elegant account of this attempt at utopia and of his family's deep connections to it.

title: 'From Sarah to Sydney' Review: The Author Was One of a Kind
summary: In her groundbreaking novel of Jewish life for young readers, Sidney Taylor created an idealized version of a darker childhood.. With autobiographical fiction, there's bound to be a gap between the story on the page and the author's experiences as they transpired in real life. So only a naive reader would expect total alignment between the immigrant Jewish household that welcomed Sarah Brenner as a newborn in 1904 and the domestic milieu she described in her acclaimed 1951 children's book, "All-of-a-Kind-Family." Still, even the jaded may be startled by certain discontinuities between fact and fiction in the world of the writer who, as a married adult, went by the name Sydney Taylor.

title: Volvo Cars Needs Investors to Value Brain Over Brawn
summary: As the Swedish car maker gears up for an initial public offering, a hyperactive first half showcases both its strategic flexibility and financial limitations. The mooted initial public offering of Volvo Cars is a must-watch test case of investor appetite for smaller car manufacturers as the industry's technological transition accelerates.

title: 'The Ledger and the Chain' Review: Human Cost
summary: Traffickers in bondage made fortunes-abetted by banks, brokers and lawyers in North and South.. The name Isaac Franklin has been largely lost to history, but his 1846 death did not go unnoticed in the nation's press-doubtless because, at his passing, Franklin was worth some $435 million in today's dollars. Obituary writers outdid themselves in hailing him as a self-made son of "Tennessee pioneers" renowned for "the management of business, for which he became afterwards so remarkable."

title: Fantasy: Back to the Round Table
summary: The Lady of Shalott isn't waiting on Lancelot any more in an updated version of the tale.. Elaine of Astolat is a minor figure in Arthurian romance. In Sir Thomas Malory's version, she's a maiden who falls in love with Lancelot and, once rejected, pines away and then drifts downriver to Camelot with a reproachful letter in her dead hand. As "The Lady of Shalott," she caught the Victorian imagination in Alfred, Lord Tennyson's poem and three famous paintings by John William Waterhouse.

title: End of Eviction Moratorium Puts Many Tenants at Risk of Losing Their Homes
summary: State and local governments have had a hard time distributing $47 billion in federal aid. State and local governments are struggling to distribute $47 billion in federal money aimed at helping tenants who can't pay rent because of the Covid-19 crisis, leaving many people at risk of being thrown out of their homes when an eviction moratorium expires on July 31.

title: The Toughest Part of Novak Djokovic's Golden Slam Is the Gold
summary: The best-of-three sets Olympic tournament introduces a level of randomness that the world No. 1 rarely encounters in majors. TOKYO-Novak Djokovic is most of the way to one of the rarest feats in sports: a sweep of all four major tennis tournaments and Olympic gold, known as a Golden Slam.

title: The Great Deflation: Wells Fargo Grounds Its Stagecoach Balloon
summary: Resume Subscription. Each fall for 13 years, Beth Wright-Smith fired up a nine-story-tall hot-air balloon shaped like a stagecoach and took to the desert skies.

title: NBCUniversal Bets Olympics Can Vault Peacock Ahead in Streaming Contest
summary: Comcast's streaming service is featuring original programming around the Tokyo Games-much of it free, including a recap show with Snoop Dogg and Kevin Hart. Kevin Hart and Snoop Dogg aren't known as sports commentators. But users of the Peacock streaming service will soon be able to get the duo's takes on Olympic pole vaulting, volleyball or-a new addition-speed climbing.

title: Sports Promoter Injected Razzle-Dazzle Into Pro Leagues
summary: Dennis Murphy, who has died at age 94, enlivened basketball and hockey with innovative ideas. Dennis Murphy, a former mayor of Buena Park, Calif., was working in public relations, organizing girls softball and serving as president of a local Optimist Club in the early 1960s. After losing a Democratic primary-election bid to run for the California state assembly, he needed another way to find a bigger stage.

title: Disney Looks to Relocate Its Theme-Park Magic Makers to Florida
summary: Company wants to send many of its famed Imagineers to a campus in Orlando, where about $570 million in tax incentives await. Walt Disney Co. parks have reopened after Covid-19 shutdowns that stretched for months, but the divisions that make the attractions hum face further uncertainty after a relocation to Florida was announced last week.

title: Economic Reality Ruins Summer Camp
summary: Facing labor shortages and delivery delays, a pricey New England summer camp gave parents and campers a lesson in today's economic strains. Sleep-away camp is a carefree place where kids can escape from the pressures of the school year and, perhaps more important, a place that lets Mom and Dad escape from their kids.

title: Rock Stars Remember More Than the Alamo
summary: Phil Collins's collection of Texas memorabilia is only the beginning. Just ask Cher.. There's been a lot of talk about the Alamo lately, with the controversial new book "Forget the Alamo" challenging just about everything we have come to believe about the epic 1836 confrontation between insurgent Texas colonists and the Mexican army.

title: 'Why Peacocks?' Review: Fool for Feathers
summary: A combat-zone reporter, Sean Flynn thought he was ready for a bigger challenge: peacock owner.. It's a good storytelling trope: Take a globe-trotting journalist, put him on a North Carolina farmette, throw in three needy peacocks and watch him scramble around in the slanting light of self-deprecation. In "Why Peacocks? An Unlikely Search for Meaning in the World's Most Magnificent Bird" (Simon & Schuster, 263 pages, $27), Sean Flynn recounts his misadventures as the naive new owner of a trio of Indian peacocks, and we can't help rooting for him.

title: Five Best: Books on Art and Culture in Occupied Paris
summary: Selected by Timothy Schaffert, the author, most recently, of the novel 'The Perfume Thief.'. By Alan Riding (2010)

title: Mysteries: 'M, King's Bodyguard' Review
summary: In Niall Leonard's gaslight thriller, spies stalk the royal family, and a Scotland Yard stalwart has to choose who to trust.. William Melville, the narrator of Niall Leonard's historical thriller "M, King's Bodyguard" (Pantheon, 264 pages, $26.95), was born in Ireland and worked as a baker before joining London's Metropolitan Police. "Over the decades," he recounts, "I had, through tenacity, low cunning and my own clumping fists, risen from beat constable to Detective Chief Superintendent Melville of Scotland Yard, champion of British justice-or notorious thug, depending on which papers you read."

title: Gas Engines, and the People Behind Them, Are Cast Aside for Electric Vehicles
summary: Resume Subscription. Steven Penkevich spent 36 years at Ford Motor Co. as part of an army of Detroit engineers who perfected the internal combustion engine, a technology dating back to the dawn of the automobile era. He developed gasoline engines for family sedans as well as thunderous Nascar racing machines.

title: Inside the Debate Over the Future of the U.S. Navy
summary: As before, the service's problem is cultural. A course correction is needed.. The recent report commissioned by members of Congress on the state of the Navy, first reported on these pages ("If War Comes, Will the U.S. Navy Be Prepared?" July 12), has raised the temperature of a debate that has been percolating in the Navy for some time. Last year, after a capital ship burned in San Diego and a high-profile firing of a Navy captain, these pages asked: Is there a larger cultural problem in the Navy? ("The Navy's Cultural Ship is Listing," July 17, 2020).

title: Big Four Auditors Fail to Meet U.K. Regulator Expectations
summary: KPMG performed the worst of the big four, with only 59% of its audits graded as good or requiring only limited improvements, according to the regulator. The U.K.'s accounting regulator said audits performed by the big four accounting firms and smaller rivals failed to meet expectations, raising troubling questions about the financial statements upon which investors rely.

title: Snap, Twitter, Facebook, TAL Education: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Major Wall Street indexes are on course to close out the week with gains. Futures are up, putting major indexes on track for weekly gains with large technology stocks driving the rally. Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's action.

title: Covid-19 Surge Hits Myanmar's Hobbled Healthcare System
summary: Doctors and nurses protesting coup refuse to staff government hospitals; some medics at risk of arrest. The scenes in Myanmar, where coronavirus cases are rising rapidly, are reminiscent of Covid-19 surges in India and Indonesia, with hospitals turning away the sick and bodies piling up at crematoriums.

title: States Get Behind Push to Pay for Diapers
summary: Demand at diaper banks is surging; federal funding and state sales-tax breaks are on the table. A push for government-funded diapers is getting new life, as more families struggle to afford the baby staple.

title: Chicago Honors Victim of 'Red Summer' Race Riots
summary: Resume Subscription. A Chicago-area cemetery will add a marker on Saturday to the grave of Eugene Williams, the first victim to die in one of the worst race riots in U.S. history, more than 100 years after he was buried.

title: More Canadian Churches Burn in Suspicious Fires
summary: Resume Subscription. TORONTO-A Coptic Orthodox church burned to the ground in the Canadian province of British Columbia on Monday, the latest in a string of church fires in this country deemed "suspicious" by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: For Big Tech, There's a New Sheriff on the Beat
summary: Head of U.K.'s CMA says it is stepping out of the shadow of the EU after Brexit. LONDON-The U.K.'s competition authority is stepping out of the shadow of the European Union, launching a flurry of new cases against big tech companies and becoming a new source of global scrutiny for the industry.

title: Bitcoin Is Failing Its First Inflation Test as Selloff Deepens
summary: Original cryptocurrency has lost about half of its value since mid-April. Bitcoin's steep selloff is undercutting the argument made by the digital currency's proponents that it's an inflation hedge.

title: Make Smart Travel Decisions as Delta Cases Rise
summary: You booked a summer vacation, and now you're nervous about Delta. Here's what to know about changing or postponing your plans.. Karen Holling, a 47-year-old homemaker in the Phoenix area, was planning to drive to Los Angeles with her stepmother later this month for a three-night stay. The pair began to reconsider as cases of the Delta variant rose. They're both fully vaccinated, but worried about the Covid-19 risk-and that businesses might shut down, keeping them from fully enjoying the trip. This week, they decided to call it off until case numbers improve.

title: The Next Target for mRNA Vaccines After Covid-19: The Flu
summary: Gene-based shots have been critical in fighting the coronavirus; now vaccine makers want to replicate that success in the yearly fight against influenza. mRNA vaccines beat out many traditional approaches in the race to develop shots against Covid-19. Now, they are squaring up to an old viral nemesis: influenza.

title: What We Know About the Origins of Covid-19
summary: Resume Subscription. It is among the world's most consequential mysteries: Where did the coronavirus that killed millions of people and shattered the global economy come from?

title: South Korea's 'Fingerless Mountaineer' Is Missing After Making History in the Himalayas
summary: Search under way to find Kim Hong-bin, who fell on his descent after becoming the first disabled person to scale the world's 14 tallest mountains. SEOUL-On Sunday, Kim Hong-bin made mountaineering history, becoming the first disabled person to scale the world's 14 tallest mountains. Now, he is missing.

title: Popular Gay TV Show in Hong Kong Draws Political Attacks, Raising Worries Over Rights
summary: The hit romance has been praised by LGBT groups, but a pro-Beijing lawmaker said it broke China's national security law. HONG KONG-A TV show about a male love triangle is proving a big hit with viewers, but criticism from pro-Beijing politicians is stirring concern that broader freedoms could be caught up in China's political crackdown, even as Hong Kong prepares to host the Gay Games in 2022.

title: Cameron Diaz and Katherine Power Discuss Fundraising, Launching a New Wine
summary: The women raised a Series A round and brought vegan wine brand Avaline to market during the pandemic. A global pandemic didn't stop actress Cameron Diaz and entrepreneur Katherine Power from launching Avaline, a vegan wine brand.

title: 'Black Widow' Enters a Gray Area
summary: Latest Marvel saga seen as a success for Disney despite theater underperformance, but reality is more complicated. Marvel's latest superhero failed to rescue movie theaters from their post-pandemic malaise. How much value the movie ensnared for parent company Walt Disney Co. is also worth questioning.

title: Why Microsoft Centered the Start Button in Windows 11
summary: The change came after years of research by a team of about 40 Microsoft designers, two of whom spoke to the Experience Report about their choices. Microsoft Corp.'s new Windows 11, coming later this year, is fairly similar to its well-received predecessor Windows 10-good news for users who don't want to relearn the operating system from scratch, as they had to do with some previous incarnations.

title: As Vaccines Do Their Work, Focus Moves to Long Covid
summary: Array of long-term symptoms afflict as much as 30% of infected people. As vaccines blunt the threat of severe illness and death from Covid-19, millions of people remain at risk of developing an array of less serious but potentially debilitating long-term symptoms of the disease that scientists call long Covid.

title: Peraton Taps Former Booz Allen CIO to Lead Tech Integration
summary: Rebecca McHale joins following two multibillion-dollar acquisitions by the government tech services provider. Peraton Corp. has named Rebecca McHale as chief information officer to lead a tech transformation following two multibillion-dollar acquisitions by the government contractor.

title: Dimons Aren't Forever, but Boards Act That Way
summary: Lavish bonuses such as those awarded to Jamie Dimon are rational from a board's point of view, but not to ordinary shareholders. Aw, you shouldn't have.

title: Tin Prices Reach Records as Delta Variant Disrupts Supply
summary: Traders are betting that electronics demand will remain strong while the coronavirus limits tin production in Southeast Asia. Tin prices are surging to all-time highs, lifted by wagers that coronavirus disruptions in Southeast Asia will fuel shortages of the industrial metal.

title: She's the Most Dominant Cyclist in the World. She's About to Retire.
summary: Anna van der Breggen has won close to everything in women's road cycling-and is a favorite to win gold in Tokyo on Sunday. Still, at season's end, she's putting away her bike to start a new chapter of her life.. At 31, the Dutch cycling star Anna van der Breggen owns a résumé that puts her among the greatest ever in the sport. There are her overall victories at prestigious stage races like the women's Giro d'Italia, which van der Breggen has won four times, including earlier this month. There are her triumphs in punchy "one-day" races like the Tour of Flanders and Amstel Gold. Van der Breggen currently possesses "double rainbows"-two rainbow-striped jerseys-for being the 2020 world champion on the road as well as the 2020 world champion in the individual time trial. With Danish rider Annika Langvad, van der Breggen even captured the grueling "Cape Epic" mountain bike race in South Africa a few years ago.

title: Grills Are the Latest IPO Fad
summary: The IPOs of two grill sellers and a SPAC deal for BBQGuys highlight bets on durability of stay-at-home trend. The searing market for newly public companies has a new obsession: grills.

title: Some Independent Directors of Bankrupt Firms Show Bias, Study Says
summary: Independent directors have incentives to build reputations as friendly to the companies hiring them, researchers say. Companies on the brink of insolvency are increasingly appointing independent directors to their boards as they prepare for a bankruptcy filing, but their neutrality is disputed by creditors, lawyers and academics.

title: Property Investors Bed Down in the Family Home
summary: Big investing firms aren't crowding out normal house buyers yet, but they are likely to become more controversial players in the residential market. Wall Street firms are more eager than ever to buy family homes. If they snap up existing supply rather than help build new dwellings, they risk killing their latest golden goose.

title: North Miami Beach's Crestview Evacuees Struggle With Weeks of Displacement
summary: Resume Subscription. NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla.-The city's closure of the 156-unit Crestview Towers Condominium on July 2 displaced dozens of families overnight. Three weeks later, they remain in a housing limbo made worse by financial struggles and complicated medical conditions.

title: Democrats Unify Behind Climate Corps
summary: Corps would employ Americans on climate-focused public-works projects like reforestation.

title: Electric-Vehicle Sales Growth Outpaces Broader Auto Industry
summary: New plug-in models from Tesla, Ford, VW and others helped to boost demand, while hurdles still remain for the technology. The auto industry's push into electric vehicles has gained traction this year with sales of these models growing at a faster clip than the broader U.S. car business.

title: 'The Skin of Our Teeth' Review: A Classic Distilled
summary: Quintessence Theatre presents a webcast version of Thornton Wilder's 1942 play about the Antrobus family and their journey through 5,000 years of human history..

title: Vodafone Shares Rise as Revenue Recovers From Pandemic
summary: Telecom firm says reduced travel has kept roaming revenue below pre-pandemic levels. Vodafone Group PLC said Friday that its quarterly revenue rebounded from the hit caused by the coronavirus pandemic last year, and that it is on track to meet its expectations for the full year.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: American Airlines, Southwest Lifted by Recovering Demand, Government Aid
summary: The two carriers were among the hardest-hit by cancellations and delays last month as they moved to restore operations amid a rebound in air travel. The travel recovery airlines had hoped for has arrived. Now the question is whether the industry can keep it going.

title: Bill Would Strip Social Media of Protections for Health Misinformation
summary: Sen. Amy Klobuchar's measure covering Covid-19 would create exception to law known as Section 230 shielding platforms from suits. WASHINGTON-Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D., Minn.) introduced a bill Thursday that would strip online platforms such as Facebook Inc. and Twitter Inc. of their liability protections if their technologies spread misinformation related to public-health emergencies, such as the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Kaseya Gets Tool to Unlock Hacked Data
summary: The tech company declined to disclose who provided the decryptor or if a ransom was paid. The technology provider at the center of a ransomware attack this month said it obtained a tool to unlock data targeted by hackers in an incident that disrupted hundreds of firms in several countries.
